taxonomicNotes: The true identity of this taxon remains unclear. This name is applied to multiple taxa within a complex of numerous cryptic species many of which are cultivated as ornametals, leading to the very wide distribution pattern (J. Leong-Škorničková pers. comm. 2020).
The name is currently applied to a complex of one widespread species and a few stenoendemic species (J. Leong-Škornicková pers. comm.).

According to Häkkinen (2013), Musa tonkinensis R.V.Valmayor, L.D.Danh & Häkkinen is assigned to Musa sect. Musa Cheesman. By this definition, M. tonkinensis is a wild relative of edible crop bananas and plantains under Taxon Group 2, according to the taxon group definition by Maxted et al. (2006).

The name Alpinia malaccensis is applied to numerous taxa within a taxonomically complicated complex, which is why the distribution pattern is so broad. Further taxonomic studies are needed to better understand the true identity of A. malaccensis and taxa embedded in this complex (J. Leong-Škorničková pers. comm. 2020).

Boesenbergia albolutea is a perennial rhizomatous herb. The species is endemic to Andaman Islands. This plant was sollected by Mr. Man from Andamans and sent to Kew in 1889, where it flowered and was identified and described as an unknown species.

This species is closely related to Etlingera metriocheilos (Griff.) R.M.Sm. (which has already been assessed as LC) and further studies will have to reveal if this taxon should be recognised and at what taxonomic rank (A.D. Poulsen pers. comm. 2020).
Although this species is believed to be a synonym of Etlingera fulgens by some (A.D. Poulsen pers. comm. 2020), it is accepted as a valid separated species for the purposes of this assessment.

Although currently accepted as valid species in POWO (2020), Etlingera fulgens is for some still a part of the E. hemisphaerica complex.

On the other hand, E. fulgens, is also is believed to be in synonymy with E. diepenhorstii according to A.D. Poulsen (pers. comm. 2020).

For the purposes of this assessment, E. fulgens is accepted here as a valid separated species.

A taxonomic revision is in preparation. This species is only known from the type collection, which comprises three sheets. The identity of the species is not in doubt. Although it resembles Globba andersonii, there are clear morphological differences between the two species.

There has been taxonomic confusion about the species identity and previous lectotypification by Theilade (1998). The typification was corrected by Leong-Škorničková (2014), and photo of the species from the type locality (Penang Hill) published by Leong-Škorničková et al. (2014). This later interpretation and geographic range is followed in this assessment, restricting the species occurrence to the type locality and, based on Ridley (1899), Maxwell Hill.
This is a species complex and is not well typified.

This is a species complex and is not well typified.

A recent molecular phylogenetic study combined with morphological studies confirmed that Amomum was polyphyletic resulting in the resurrection of Conamomum, Meistera and Wurfbainia and the creation of three new genera Epiamomum, Lanxangia and Sundamomum (de Boer et al. 2018).

A recent molecular phylogenetic study combined with morphological studies confirmed that Amomum was polyphyletic resulting in the resurrection of Conamomum, Meistera and Wurfbainia and the creation of three new genera Epiamomum, Lanxangia and Sundamomum (de Boer et al. 2018).
This is a species complex and is not well typified.

A recent molecular phylogenetic study combined with morphological studies confirmed that Amomum was polyphyletic resulting in the resurrection of Conamomum, Meistera and Wurfbainia and the creation of three new genera Epiamomum, Lanxangia and Sundamomum (de Boer et al. 2018).

This is a species complex; collections from Thailand and Indonesia are known as Wurfbainia testaca and W. compactum.

This taxon has been previously assessed as Zingiber montanum, but—after Bai et al. (2020) study of the identity, taxonomy and nomenclatural history of Z. montanum, Z. purpureum and their synonyms—it was concluded that the species subject to this assessment corresponds to be in reality Z. purpureum.

Zingiber purpureum is the name that was given to this plant when it was described for the first time, but along the years it was misidentified and confused with Z. montanum (Bai et al. 2020).

Zingiber purpureum is the widely cultivated plant known as Cassumunar Ginger, used in traditional medicine (Bai et al. 2020), and for which there is lack of information regarding its place of origin.

According to Häkkinen (2013), Musa lanceolata Warb. ex K. Schum. is assigned to Musa sect. Musa Cheesman. By this definition, M. lanceolata is a wild relative of edible crop bananas and plantains under Taxon Group 2, according to the taxon group definition by Maxted et al. (2006).
